issues.text: whether the order of the Commissioner under s. 33A of the Income-tax Act was an administrative act and therefore no writ of certiorari would lie to the High Court to quash that order under Art. 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gopal Singh, learned counsel for the Revenue, while supporting the order of the High Court raised a preliminary objection, namely, that the order of the Commissioner under s. 33A of the Income-tax Act was administrative act and, therefore, no writ of certiorari would lie to the High Court to quash that order under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the affidavit filed in support of the writ petition was highly unsatisfactory such that the petition could not be entertained, the facts were incomplete and confused, and there was no force in the revision petition on merits

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the said application in limine mainly on the following three grounds 1 the affidavit filed in support of the writ petition was highly unsatisfactory and on the basis of such an affidavit it was not possible to entertain the petition 2 the facts given in the affidavit were incomplete and confused and 3 even on merits, there was no force in the revision petition

issues.text: whether, even if the affidavit was defective, the High Court should have given an opportunity to the appellant to rectify the defects

anchor.surface_text: That apart, if the affidavit was defective in any manner the High Court, instead of dismissing the petition in limine, should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to file a better affidavit complying with the provisions of r. 1 of Ch. XXII of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Section 29 of the Act reads When any tax, penalty or interest is due in consequence of any order passed under or in pursuance of this Act,

holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the Commissioner under s. 33A(2) of the Income-tax Act is judicial/quasi-judicial in nature, requiring a duty to act judicially, and thus a writ of certiorari lies to quash such an order under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie the jurisdiction conferred under s. 33A 2 of the Act is a judicial one. The order that is brought before the Commissioner affects the right of the assessee. It is implicit in revisional jurisdiction that the revising authority shall give an opportunity to the parties affected to put forward their case in the manner prescribed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies tests for quasi-judicial act: affects rights of assessee, duty to act judicially inferred from statute (opportunity, inquiry), distinguishes Privy Council observations as obiter and inapplicable; rejects High Court precedents following it.

holdings.text: Even assuming the Commissioner's order is administrative, a writ of mandamus lies under Art. 226 against the Income-tax Officer for failure to perform statutory duty under s. 29.

anchor.surface_text: What the appellant complains is that the Income-tax Officer in terms of s. 29 of the Act is under an obligation to issue a demand notice. If the said contention was correct, he did not discharge the duty imposed on him by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative ground: statutory duty on ITO independent of Commissioner's order; High Court power to mould reliefs.

holdings.text: The affidavit filed in support of the writ petition complied with Allahabad High Court Rules Ch. XXII r.1(2), as deponent's knowledge includes facts from perusal of records and annexed documents.

anchor.surface_text: The application filed in the High Court certainly complied with the provisions of sub-r. 2 of r. 1 of Ch. XXII of the Rules of Court of the Allahabad High Court. It set out concisely in numbered paragraphs the facts upon which the applicant relied...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deponent as pairokar conversant with facts; specifies basis (personal knowledge, records); annexed true copies prove themselves.

holdings.text: If the affidavit was defective, the High Court should have given the petitioner opportunity to rectify instead of dismissing in limine.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, if the affidavit was defective in any manner the High Court, instead of dismissing the petition in limine, should have given the appellant a reasonable opportunity to file a better affidavit complying with the provisions of r. 1 of Ch. XXII of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness under court rules; not fatal defect warranting dismissal without chance to cure.

holdings.text: The facts in the affidavit were complete and not confused.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we agree with the High Court that the facts given in the affidavit are incomplete and confused. On the other hand, a careful perusal of the affidavit, along with the documents annexed thereto, discloses clearly the appellants case it gives the necessary facts and the reliefs sought for.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Careful perusal shows narrative clear, no missing links; supports case adequately.

holdings.text: Revision petition under s.33A(2) was maintainable against ITO's order as no appeal lay to AAC (no s.23(3) order or s.29 notice issued).

anchor.surface_text: namely i whether a revision lay to the Commissioner under s. 33-A 2 of the Act against the order of the Income-tax Officer... As no appeal lay to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner against the calculations made by the Income-tax Officer, the Commissioner had certainly power to revise the said order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.33A(2) bars revision only if appeal maintainable/pending; here appeal dismissed as not maintainable.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer is under mandatory duty to issue notice of demand under s.29 when tax due consequent to an order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 29 of the Act reads When any tax, penalty or interest is due in consequence of any order passed under or in pursuance of this Act,... Pursuant to the directions given by. the Tribunal the Income-tax Officer made fresh calculations under the head capital gains and ascertained the amount due from the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'shall serve'; ITO computed tax due post-Tribunal directions but failed to issue notice.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari issues quashing Commissioner's order; writ of mandamus issues directing ITO to pass order and issue s.29 notice.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the order of the High Court is set aside and we issue a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Commissioner and a writ of mandamus directing the Income- tax Officer to pass an order and issue a notice in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: errors in High Court dismissal; merits require revision/entertainment and ITO compliance.

edges.explanation: Statutory provision on s.29 demand notice grounds holding of mandatory duty on ITO
The holding that no appeal lay to AAC (enabling revision under s.33A(2)) is grounded in Section 30 of the Income-tax Act 1922, which governs appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Section 30 addresses the issue by defining conditions for appeal to AAC, relevant to determining if revision lay instead.
Concept c9 (Section 23 requires assessment order for appeal) grounds h6's reasoning that no appeal lay to AAC due to absence of s.23(3) order.
